summary: This is a sentencing memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys, objecting to the Presentence Investigation Report (PSR). The memorandum argues that the 2003 Sentencing Guidelines should apply instead of the 2004 Guidelines, contests several sentencing enhancements, and claims the correct sentencing range is 51-63 months, not the 292-365 months calculated by the Probation Office.

events.title: Effective Date of 2004 Sentencing Guidelines
events.description: The 2004 United States Sentencing Guidelines took effect. The defense argues applying them to Maxwell would be an ex post facto violation if her criminal conduct ended before this date.

events.title: Filing of Sentencing Memorandum
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team files this memorandum objecting to the Presentence Investigation Report and arguing for a lower sentencing range.

events.title: Alleged End of Offense Conduct
events.description: The second superseding indictment alleges the criminal conduct ended 'in or about 2004.' The defense argues it ended before November 1, 2004, while the prosecution suggests it continued through the end of 2004.

events.title: Maxwell 'Moves On' from Epstein
events.description: Defense claims evidence shows Ghislaine Maxwell had ended her romantic relationship with Epstein, stopped actively managing his properties, and began a relationship with Ted Waitt by this time.

keyFacts: The defense argues applying the 2004 Sentencing Guidelines to Ghislaine Maxwell would violate the Ex Post Facto Clause, as her criminal conduct allegedly ended before November 1, 2004.
The memorandum contests a five-point enhancement under USSG ยง 4B1.5 for being a 'Repeat and Dangerous Sex Offender,' arguing Maxwell is not a danger to the public and poses no risk of recidivism.
The defense claims the correct sentencing range under the 2003 Guidelines, after removing contested enhancements, is 51-63 months, not the 292-365 months calculated by the Probation Office.
The document references multiple minor victims identified by pseudonyms (e.g., 'Jane-1', 'Jane-2', 'Jane-3') and argues the trial record does not support certain enhancements related to them.
The defense asserts that by 2002 or 2003, Ghislaine Maxwell had stopped actively participating in the offense conduct and had been replaced by another employee, Sarah Kellen.
